ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about women throughout the middle ages who I never would have known existed otherwise. I was definitely unaware of just how many women were able to carve out places for themselves in such patriarchal societies, and I'm so glad to have read about them in this course.

I learned a great deal about the lives of women from various social groups in medieval Europe, as well as their place in literature, religion and art. I also improved my ability to read archaic Italian.

This was a terrific class! As a lover of history and women studies, this class introduced me to so many amazing women and their accomplishments, some of whose texts I willingly engage with outside the classroom setting.
I improved my ability to read and analyze primary sources! I also gained insight about historical bias and interpreting secondary sources.
Learned how to examine and analysis history papers and write one.
I learned about religiosity and society during medieval Europe. I learned how to engage critically with primary texts (letters, poems, and other manuscripts).

I learned so much about women in the Middle Ages- both conceptions of women by men and broader society, but also how women conceived of themselves in their letters, books, and other writings. We spent a lot of time analyzing primary sources, which was incredibly interesting, and also doing comparison of texts. I think my close reading skills really improved and my knowledge of the Middle Ages was expanded quite a bit.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Readings were generally interesting.
Weaknesses: a bit all over the place and unorganized with the readings, presentations are repetitive and a bit unnecessary.

Lessons were engaging. Presentations were a good way to learn from fellow students. Reading responses were helpful in understanding the texts. Guest lecturers provided additional insight into the material. Classroom discussions were productive, although some students talked too long and too often.

Strengths: Professor Pellegrino is one of the loveliest I have had the pleasure of learning from. Her genuine passion and excitement for the class (both topic-wise and student engagement wise) make the class much more enjoyable.

strengths: great selection of readings and women to discuss, helpful homework assignments to work on writing skills

weaknesses: more guided discussions, a framework for what we should look for when we're doing the readings
The discussions were thought-provoking and engaging! I loved the readings and the final paper assignment!

strengths: diverse syllabus and appropriate reading load
weaknesses: discussion was sometimes hard to engage in

Honestly I don't think this course had any weaknesses! Potentially a smaller class size would be nice, but everyone in the course contributed meaningfully. The presentations were a nice way to learn historical context for the women that we discussed in class, and the discussion posts actually mattered and weren't just filler assignments. The primary sources and other readings assigned were a manageable length and were all impactful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely recommend taking this course if you're interested in learning more about women who are able to make the best of their situations and find power even in supremely male-dominated societies!
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in medieval Europe, women's history or Italian literature.
Yes! Because Professor Pellegrino is so understanding, there tends to be less work for this class than most other humanity courses, but the readings and assignments tend to be very enjoyable anyway.
I would absolutely recommend this course. It was a very cool subject and well thought out!
Yes it is a great humanities class.
Yes! Deborahs a wonderful professor and course material is very interesting and approachable for someone not well-versed in the history or Christianity.

Yes! This was one of my favorite classes at Yale so far, and it inspired me to pursue the Medieval Studies certificate. Even if you aren't super interested in the Middle Ages, this is a great way to learn about women in history, even those that are not the most well known. None of the work is overwhelming and everything is super well communicated to students, plus Professor Pellegrino was really flexible and accommodating. The guest lecturers are also very knowledgable and provide great insights to the texts.

extras.title: HUMS 210 01/ITAL 317 01/LITR 180 01/WGSS 317 01 - Women in the Middle Ages TR
